comments.text:
Here's one tax tip I push that I am constantly amazed there are no internet financial guru's pounding the table advocating the same...
If a couple each have a traditional IRA of their own, name your children/heirs as beneficiaries of some or all of the account.  My wife and I set up ours this way.  When she unexpectedly died at 70 our two sons received 80% of her Traditional and Roth IRA's.  They have 10 years to manage the distributions from their inherited IRA, $400k+ each.  If I survive at least 10 more years they will have another separate 10 year period to manage distributions from the IRA's they will inherit from me.  As the survivor, I have more time to continue making Roth conversions to lessen their eventual tax burden later.
comments.author: @GreggSwartzbaugh

comments.text: one point he accurately slides over quickly regarding the step up. On inheriting the Rental property example, you won't pay taxes on the $2MM gain...but i'm pretty sure you still have to pay taxes on the original $1MM investment.  I do not believe this is a completely tax free scenario but would appreciate if anyone could weigh on on this.

comments.text:
It will make more  sense to inherit instead to be gifted while parents alive, if only you are the only child. However, if you have siblings and you are the only one who carries the burden of a caregiver, then being gifted while parents are live is the best option you have.
It is all about perspective!
comments.author: @SlaveNation1

comments.text:
What's pass free gift 🤨
Or pass gift wealth free
comments.author: @YasmineNazrine

comments.text:
Here's one tax tip I push that I am constantly amazed there are no internet financial guru's pounding the table advocating the same...
If a couple each have a traditional IRA of their own, name your children/heirs as beneficiaries of some or all of the account.  My wife and I set up ours this way.  When she unexpectedly died at 70 our two sons received 80% of her Traditional and Roth IRA's.  They have 10 years to manage the distributions from their inherited IRA, $400k+ each.  If I survive at least 10 more years they will have another separate 10 year period to manage distributions from the IRA's they will inherit from me.  As the survivor, I have more time to continue making Roth conversions to lessen their eventual tax burden later.
comments.author: @GreggSwartzbaugh

comments.text: one point he accurately slides over quickly regarding the step up. On inheriting the Rental property example, you won't pay taxes on the $2MM gain...but i'm pretty sure you still have to pay taxes on the original $1MM investment.  I do not believe this is a completely tax free scenario but would appreciate if anyone could weigh on on this.
comments.author: @crookedsights304

comments.text: All young sons not smart
comments.author: @YasmineNazrine

comments.text: My husband Bobby did this another way.  He gave his heirs $10K per year for a very long period.  By the time he died at 86, most of it had been passed on.  I distributed the rest of it, according to his will, as his executrix.🎉
